QCA (2)
RODA (3)

My research is mainly focused on methodological aspects of the social science research. In particular, I have made a number of contributions to both the theory of the Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA), and also to the software implementation of this research method. My R package QCA is now the default standard for this type of research, being taught in university curricula and summer schools, all over the world.

My other research interest is related to data documentation. I strongly believe that data is useless, and its value decreases over time, unless we manage to establish a long term storage containing the context in which the data was collected. Such metadata (data about data) is handled by the Data Documentation Initiative (DDI) standard, for which I develop software (into another R package called DDIwR) that empowers researchs to quickly document their data and create a single XML document containing both data and metadata, for long term storage.

Finally, it needs mentioning what I consider another one of my proud-worthy accomplishments, the R package declared. It tackles what many consider a serious shortcoming of the R statistical environment, the existence of a single missing value, called NA. But social sciences have many values to explain why a certain value is missing (maybe the respondend did not know what to respond, or might not have wanted to respond because of a too sensitive question, or simply the question was not applicable). Package declared makes it possible to declare value labels and missing values, and offers a wide range of functions to deal with these additional values that base R does not cover.
